channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Finland’s Move to Join NATO Upends Putin’s War Aims
item.description: Neutral Finland’s leaders unequivocally said they intended to seek membership in the alliance, with Sweden expected to do the same, inviting new threats from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers atop a captured Russian tank on Thursday in the village of Hrushuvakha, on the front lines of fighting with Russian forces in the Kharkiv region.

item.title: North Korea Reports 6 Deaths as Covid-19 Spreads ‘Explosively’
item.description: The country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said 187,800 people were in quarantine, and state TV showed him wearing a mask for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A TV broadcast in Seoul on Thursday showed North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, wearing a mask after the North confirmed its first Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Investigation of Journalist’s Killing May Hinge on Bullet
item.description: The Palestinian Authority said it would not let Israeli officials examine the bullet that killed Shireen Abu Akleh in the occupied West Bank during an Israeli raid. Israel said that is the only way to determine who fired it.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Life in a Ukrainian Unit: Diving for Cover, Waiting for Western Weapons
item.description: Analysts say the outcome of fighting now is riding on the accuracy, quantity and the striking power of long-range weapons. Ukraine is pleading for more.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier at a short-range artillery position in southern Ukraine monitors Russian movements in the distance.

item.title: U.K. Donor Said to Have Funneled Russian Money to Tories
item.description: The cash was part of a fund-raising blitz that helped propel Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s party to victory in 2019. Records track $630,225 to a Russian bank account.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley

item.title: Families Reel Outside El Salvador Prisons After Gang Violence Crackdowns
item.description: Dozens of women wait outside a detention facility for news of their loved ones after a crackdown on gang violence resulted in the imprisonment of more than 25,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives of Jonathan González López, 21, outside a prison in San Salvador after he was arrested.

item.title: Boris Johnson Sidesteps Question on Donation Flagged as Russia-Linked
item.description: Britain’s prime minister said all donations are disclosed “in the normal way.” The Conservative Party gave no sign it would return the money.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson chairing a cabinet meeting in Stoke-on-Trent, Britain, on Thursday.

item.title: Africa’s First Covid-19 Vaccine Factory Has Not Received a Single Order
item.description: Aspen Pharmacare, in South Africa, was licensed to produce the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. It was hailed as an answer to Africa’s struggle to get access to vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Walking past the site of Aspen Pharmacare’s Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine factory in Gqeberha, South Africa, last October.

item.title: Interview With Gay Couple Sparks Backlash in Indonesia
item.description: The segment on a popular podcast hosted by Deddy Corbuzier enraged religious leaders, highlighting the limits of tolerance for gay people in the Muslim-majority nation.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Supporters of same-sex marriage celebrating its legalization in Taiwan in 2019.

item.title: Kim Jong-un Orders Lockdown as North Korea Reports First Covid Cases
item.description: The country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, ordered a national lockdown after a subvariant of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus was found in the capital.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Kim Won Jin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Employees spraying disinfectant on surfaces as part of preventative measures against the coronavirus at a children’s department store in Pyongyang, North Korea.

item.title: Biden Hosts Southeast Asian Leaders as He Tries to Return Focus to China
item.description: The leaders at the two-day summit in Washington will discuss a variety of topics, but the president plans to use it to show a united front against Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden, center, with leaders of Southeast Asian nations at the White House on Thursday. As a candidate, he promised to make China a central focus of his foreign policy.

item.title: India’s Hindu-Muslim Tensions Reveal a Worrisome New Pattern
item.description: As a national campaign by right-wing groups inflames local tensions, Muslim communities are facing the harshest punishments, according to activists, analysts and retired officials.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar, Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Anindito Mukherjee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scene in Khargone, where buildings were demolished in mostly Muslim neighborhoods in the wake of violent clashes.

item.title: Bulgaria Takes Unusual Stand Against Russia With Sanctions
item.description: Bulgaria has imposed economic sanctions on Russia, offered to repair broken military equipment for Ukraine and expelled Russian diplomats.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins, Boryana Dzhambazova and Nanna Heitmann

item.title: Shireen Abu Akleh, Palestinian Journalist, Dies, Aged 51
item.description: Ms. Abu Akleh, 51, a Palestinian American reporter who was killed in the West Bank on Wednesday, was a household name across the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Shireen Abu Akleh, reporting in Jerusalem for Al Jazeera, was one of the best known Palestinian journalists.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Finland moves to join NATO.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lauri Heino/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of a Finnish Army brigade during exercises this year in Taipalsaari, close to the southeastern border with Russia.

item.title: Rand Paul Delays $40 Billion in Aid for Ukraine
item.description: Mr. Paul had sought to alter the bill to include requiring that an inspector general monitor the spending.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: People receive humanitarian aid supplies in the eastern city of Kharkiv, on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Embraces Finland’s Move Toward NATO Membership. What About Ukraine?
item.description: Ukraine has been considered too full of corruption and too devoid of democratic institutions to make membership likely for years, if not decades, to come.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The Finnish Parliament on Thursday. The White House welcomed the announcement by Finnish leaders that their country should “apply for NATO membership without delay.”

item.title: Biden’s Summit of the Americas Threatened By Boycotts
item.description: Latin American heads of state are threatening to skip the event in Los Angeles, putting at risk the White House’s agenda in a region gripped by upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico said he would not attend the summit if the Biden administration carries out its intent to not invite Latin America’s autocratic governments.

item.title: Finland Moves to Join NATO, Upending Putin’s Ukraine War Aims
item.description: Neutral Finland’s leaders unequivocally said they intended to seek membership in the alliance, with Sweden expected to do the same, inviting new threats from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A convoy of Ukrainian armored vehicles near the frontlines in the Donetsk region on Thursday.

item.title: Why a Bullet Is the Focus of Investigations In Journalist’s Killing
item.description: The Palestinian Authority said it would not let Israeli officials examine the bullet that killed Shireen Abu Akleh. Israel said that is the only way to determine who fired it.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Raja Abdulrahim and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: The day after she was killed, Palestinian artists were already at work painting a mural of Shireen Abu Akleh in Jenin, a city in the northern West Bank.

item.title: As Southern Africa Cases Climb, Health Officials Worry About Testing Drop
item.description: New reported cases in South Africa have increased 80 percent, from the average two weeks ago, and deaths have increased 44 percent.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Testing for the coronavirus in Johannesburg last week. Cases in Southern Africa have risen significantly over the previous week, according to the World Health Organization.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The Fateful Bullet
item.description: Israeli and Palestinian authorities are divided over how to investigate the killing of the Al Jazeera journalist in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Family and friends of Shireen Abu Akleh carried her body as she arrived in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: F.B.I. Told Israel It Wanted Pegasus Hacking Tool for Investigations
item.description: A 2018 letter from the bureau to the Israeli government is the clearest documentary evidence to date that the agency weighed using the spyware for law enforcement operations.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Pegasus is produced by an Israeli firm, NSO Group, which needs to gain approval from the Israeli government before it can sell the hacking tool to a foreign government.

item.title: Biden Administration Cancels Oil Drilling Sales in Alaska and Gulf of Mexico
item.description: Republicans link the move to rising gas prices while the administration said it was a result of conflicting legal opinions and a lack of interest among bidders.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: An oil and gas platform in the Cook Inlet of Alaska in 2013.

item.title: U.K. Police Issue More Fines for Parties at Downing Street
item.description: Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, was not among those affected, his office said, though neither it, nor the police, named those who were.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: London’s Metropolitan Police have identified more than 100 cases of lawbreaking in government offices including Downing Street.

item.title: Thailand Is Easing Weed Laws and Giving Away Cannabis Plants
item.description: The Southeast Asian country will soon allow residents to grow cannabis for medicinal use. Smoking pot recreationally still carries harsh penalties.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A greenhouse at the Rak Jang farm in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand, one of the first in the country to grow medical marijuana with official permission.

item.title: Who Is ‘Wagatha Christie’? Let Us Explain.
item.description: The feud between two television personalities has made its way to a London courtroom and the front of British tabloids. Let us explain.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Left, Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: Coleen Rooney, left, and Rebekah Vardy arrived at court in London on Thursday.

item.title: At Biden’s Summit, Other Nations Pledge Billions to Bolster Pandemic Response
item.description: The meeting was meant to reinvigorate the response as vaccination and testing lag. Many attendees said Covid fatigue had become nearly as big a danger as Covid itself.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: A woman receiving a booster shot of a coronavirus vaccine in Soweto, South Africa, earlier this month.

item.title: Inflation Anger
item.description: Inflation is still high — and many Americans are upset.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Packing up groceries after shopping at Costco in Marina Del Ray, Calif.

item.title: Biden Orders Federal Flags to Fly at Half-Staff as U.S. Covid Toll Nears One Million
item.description: The president said in a formal statement that the United States must ‘remain vigilant’ against a virus that has ‘forever changed’ the country.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: National Park employees lowered American flags to half-staff on Thursday to mark the coming milestone of one million U.S. coronavirus deaths.

item.title: These Dancers Escaped the War. Their Journeys Are Just Beginning.
item.description: Hundreds of ballet dancers and students fled Ukraine after Russia’s invasion. With opportunities scarce, many will have to keep moving if they want to keep dancing.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Melissa Schriek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victoria Glazunova, Kate Myklukha and Polina Loshchylina of the Dutch National Ballet.

item.title: Finland’s Leaders Urge NATO Membership ‘Without Delay’
item.description: Public opinion in Finland has shifted significantly in favor of joining the alliance in the 11 weeks since Russia invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanna Marin, left, and President Sauli Niinisto in February. On thursday they announced their support for Finland to join NATO, in Helsinki on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Forecasts for the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for humanitarian aid supplies in the city of Kharkiv, in eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: The Milky Way’s Black Hole Comes to Light
item.description: The Event Horizon Telescope has once again caught sight of the “unseeable.”
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration/National Science Foundation
item.media:description: The first direct image of Sagittarius A*, the black hole at the center of the Milky Way.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Journalist Killed in the West Bank
item.description: Plus uncertainty about China’s wheat harvest and religious violence in India.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Shireen Abu Akleh, reporting in Jerusalem for Al Jazeera, was one of the best known Palestinian journalists.

item.title: Ukraine Launches First War Crimes Trial for Russian Soldier
item.description: A 21-year-old Russian soldier is accused of following orders to shoot an unarmed cyclist four days into Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Only a Third of Americans Were Worried About Covid in April, Poll Finds
item.description: The survey, from Gallup, was conducted between April 15 and April 23, at a time when new cases were increasing after plummeting from highs seen during the winter Omicron surge.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Outside a comedy club in March in Manhattan.

item.title: Israel’s Teetering Government Breathes Again as Arab Party Rejoins
item.description: A small Islamist party decided to end its freeze on participating in the fragile eight-way coalition, granting it at least a temporary reprieve.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel, lower left, during the opening of the summer session of Parliament in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: Ukrainians Fight Russian Troops Up Close Along the Eastern Front
item.description: In some villages along the front, Ukrainian and Russian soldiers face off at close quarters, sometimes within eyesight of one another.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Photographs by Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers of the Ukrainian Army’s Carpathian Sich Battalion donned their gear at an underground base while they waited for artillery fire on their position to subside.

item.title: Air Pollution Can Mean More, or Fewer, Hurricanes. It Depends Where You Live.
item.description: Smog from factories and cars has led to more storms in the Atlantic Ocean, but fewer in the Pacific. A new study explains why.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: Four storms off the east coast of North America in September 2020.

item.title: India’s Top Court Suspends Colonial-Era Sedition Law
item.description: The law has been used to quash dissent and is not in tune with the times, the court said. Its action does not overturn the law, though, only Parliament can do that.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: The Supreme Court of India halted a colonial-era sedition law on Wednesday.

item.title: Economic Toll of Russia’s War in Ukraine Tests Western Solidarity
item.description: Russia’s president is calculating that Western leaders will tire before he does of a protracted struggle in Ukraine, especially if the price is turbocharged inflation and energy shortages.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers with the Carpathian Sich Batalion reviewing drone footage of an attack against Russian forces in the Kharkiv region on Wednesday.

item.title: Report Catalogs Abuse of Native American Children at Former Government Schools
item.description: Interior Secretary Deb Haaland called for a review last year, after the discovery of hundreds of unmarked graves of children who attended similar schools in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Interior Secretary Deb Haaland led an effort to search the grounds of former boarding schools to identify the remains of Native American children.

item.title: New Zealand Border Will Fully Reopen at the End of July
item.description: The move comes two months ahead of schedule, in an attempt to speed up economic recovery.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Jed Bradley/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Travelers arrive from Los Angeles at the Auckland International Airport, after New Zealand loosened travel restrictions on May 2.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Arrest Former Bishop in National Security Case
item.description: Cardinal Joseph Zen, 90, was among three held for their work with a legal aid group that helped protesters and that officials accuse of colluding with foreign powers.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cardinal Joseph Zen, 90, has been critical of the official crackdown in Hong Kong.

item.title: Lufthansa Apologizes After Jewish People Were Barred From Flight
item.description: Passengers said that after landing in Germany, more than 100 people were blocked from boarding a connecting flight to Hungary, after a handful of passengers disobeyed a mask requirement.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Lufthansa Airlines said it regretted blocking a large number of people from a flight to Budapest last week after a few passengers did not comply with its mask requirement.

item.title: To Keep Putin and His Oligarchs Afloat, It Takes a System
item.description: Out of a halting attempt at democratization grew a corrupt ecosystem that has proved very difficult for the Russian elite to resist.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: The $700 million superyacht Scheherazade, at the port of Marina di Carrara in Tuscany this month.

item.title: Nearly One-Third of Ukraine’s Jobs Are Lost Amid War, U.N. Labor Agency Says
item.description: The report highlights the grim economic toll of Russia’s aggression and the challenges that lie ahead for Ukraine and other nations.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman

item.title: E.U. Will No Longer Recommend Masks for Air Travel
item.description: The decision came as countries across the bloc were loosening restrictions in response to the current rates of vaccination and naturally acquired immunity.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Boris Roessler/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Travelers at Frankfurt Airport in Germany last month. The European Union is ending face mask requirements on planes and in airports.

item.title: Canada’s Trucker Protests Have a New Political Champion
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau condemned the protest as illegal. Now some of his key opponents are embracing it.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in downtown Ottawa in February. In response to the protests, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada invoked an emergencies act.

item.title: Few Republicans Confront Trump. What Distinguishes Them?
item.description: What distinguishes the few Republicans willing to confront Donald Trump?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Ky. and House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy outside the West Wing, last year.

item.title: ‘Tantura’ Documentary Reopens Debate About Israel’s Foundational Story
item.description: Israeli soldiers had long denied killing prisoners after capturing an Arab seaside town, days after Israel’s creation. A new film provides fresh evidence — reopening a debate about Israel’s foundational story.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dor Beach: The parking lot at this Mediterranean beach town is the latest arena for the battle over Israel’s founding story.

item.title: Shireen Abu Akleh of Al Jazeera Is Killed in West Bank
item.description: The network and Palestinian authorities blamed Israeli troops for the killing. Israel said the blame could lie with Palestinian gunmen.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Al Jazeera, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Shireen Abu Akleh, a journalist for Al Jazeera, during one of her reports from Jerusalem.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russian advances in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valentina led her blind mother, Nina, aboard an evacuation train in Pokrovsk, in the Donbas region of Ukraine.

item.title: Leonid Kravchuk, First President of Ukraine, Dies at 88
item.description: Days after his election, he signed a multinational agreement that formally declared the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: President Bill Clinton, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and President Leonid Kravchuk of Ukraine in 1994, after signing a nuclear disarmament agreement at the Kremlin.

item.title: Iran Says It Will Execute Ahmadreza Djalali, Swedish-Iranian Accused of Spying
item.description: Ahmadreza Djalali denies he spied for Israel or helped it kill Iranian nuclear scientists.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: A protest in Turin, Italy, in 2020 against Iran sentencing an Iranian-Swedish doctor, Ahmadreza Djalali, to death.

item.title: Russia Was Behind Cyberattack in Run-Up to Ukraine War, Investigation Finds
item.description: The February attack rattled Pentagon officials and private industry because it revealed new vulnerabilities in global communications systems.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Kate Conger
item.media:description: Investigators said the Russian military intelligence agency took satellite communications in Ukraine offline. The attack came before the Feb. 24 invasion launched by President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Ukraine War’s Geographic Reality: Russia Has Seized Much of the East
item.description: Despite many stumbles and setbacks, the Russian military has gained near total control of the Donbas region, giving the Kremlin huge leverage in any future talks.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boarding an evacuation train at the Pokrovsk train station on Tuesday in the Donbas region of Ukraine.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: South Korea’s New President
item.description: Plus protests in the Philippines and a weakened Japanese yen.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoon Suk-yeol, South Korea’s new president, at his inauguration.

item.title: Spain’s Intelligence Leader Ousted Over Agency’s Use of Pegasus Spyware
item.description: Paz Esteban, the first woman to hold the job, was caught up in a scandal over her agency’s use of Pegasus spyware.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Paz Esteban, the chief of Spain’s intelligence service, arriving last week to appear before a parliamentary committee to discuss how her agency had used Israeli spyware on the phones of Catalan politicians.
